docs.lead_paragraph: That the overall health of America's people has sharply improved over the past few decades is a medical mantra, a testimonial to astonishing lifesaving and life-extending therapies, technology-driven diagnostic techniques and research advances. The rate of infant mortality has declined 16 percent in the last 10 years, maternal mortality has fallen sharply, and rapid progress had been made in reducing deaths from stroke and cardiovascular disease.

headline.main: Trying to Bridge the 'Death Gap' Confronting Minority Groups

docs.abstract: Comment on grim disparity in health between blacks and other Americans; two African-American physicians who studied issue, W Michael Byrd and Linda A Clayton, say reasons for disparities are many and intertwined, but contend that behind many of them is race-biased system of health care delivery that has its roots in distant past; they argue their case in their new book, An American Health Dilemma: A Medical History of African Americans and the Problem of Race: Beginnings to 1900; photos (L)

headline.main: Caution, Festive Candles Can Be Deadly

docs.lead_paragraph: When Phill Wilson, the executive director of the African American AIDS Policy and Training Institute at the University of Southern California, talks about AIDS in the black community, he doesn't try to soften the blunt edges of his words. ''Let's be clear, when you hear about women and AIDS or babies with AIDS or now even men who sleep with men who have AIDS, whether it's stated or not, those are overwhelmingly black women, black babies and black men,'' he said.

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH: Phill Wilson; Speaking Out to Make AIDS an Issue of Color

docs.abstract: Interview with Phill Wilson, exec dir of African American AIDS Policy and Training Institute at University of Southern California; Wilson, working for more than decade on AIDS research, policy, treatment and prevention issues, has observed from close range how silence and denial fueled spread of AIDS among African-Americans; statistics from Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows that AIDS is leading killer of black men ages 18-44 and second-leading killer of black women that age; photo (M)
